title: R40829
content: Legislation is introduced in the House or Senate in different forms: bill, joint resolution, concurrent resolution, and simple resolution. Bills and joint resolutions can become law, while simple and concurrent resolutions are used for internal matters or expressing sentiments. In the 111th Congress, 1,946 pieces of legislation received floor action in the House, with a breakdown of approximately 45% bills/joint resolutions and 55% simple/concurrent resolutions. Of these, 1,796 originated in the House and 150 in the Senate. In the 111th Congress, the House considered more legislation sponsored by Democratic Party Members than by Republicans or independents. Majority party Members had a higher ratio of sponsorship for measures receiving initial House floor action, with Democrats sponsoring 76% of all measures and 81% of lawmaking forms. The ratio varied based on the parliamentary procedure used, with Democrats sponsoring 73% of measures considered under the Suspension of the Rules procedure. In the 111th Congress, measures considered under the Suspension of the Rules procedure were sponsored by Democrats (27%), Republicans (27%), and political independents (less than 1%). The House generally uses this procedure for non-controversial measures with bipartisan support, requiring votes from minority party Members. In contrast, all measures initially brought to the floor under a special rule were sponsored by majority party Members. During the 111th Congress, the majority party sponsored most measures brought to the House floor by unanimous consent. The House used various parliamentary mechanisms to bring legislation for initial consideration, including privileged business like appropriations measures. During the 111th Congress, the House used special rules to consider measures, including appropriations, despite being privileged business. Most legislation was brought up through Suspension of the Rules, allowing quick action with limited debate and no amendments. During the 112th Congress, the House Republican leadership implemented additional policies for the Suspension of the Rules procedure, limiting its use for certain legislation and requiring measures to be available for three days before consideration. In the 111th Congress, 78% of legislation receiving House floor action was initially brought up using the Suspension of the Rules procedure. During the 111th Congress, 86% of bills and joint resolutions receiving floor action came up by Suspension of the Rules, with 92% originating in the House and 8% in the Senate. Certain types of legislation are privileged, allowing them to be called up for consideration when the House is not considering another matter. Privileged resolutions in the House include rules, committee assignments, correcting enrollments, adjournment, and questions of the privileges of the House. These resolutions are considered under specific House rules and constitutional provisions. Privileged resolutions in the House, including questions of the privileges of the House, are resolutions that affect the rights, safety, dignity, and integrity of House proceedings. This also includes resolutions expressing condolences over the death of a Representative or President, as well as organizational measures like notifying the President of the House assembly. In the 111th Congress, 269 measures, 14% of those receiving floor action, were considered privileged business in the House. Most were non-lawmaking resolutions, with a few bills and joint resolutions. Special rules from the Rules Committee were the most common type of privileged business. Special rules, also known as "order of business resolutions," regulate the House's consideration of specific legislation by determining debate time, amendments, and waivers of points of order. The Committee on Rules has jurisdiction over these resolutions and reports them to the House for consideration. While only a small percentage of legislation comes through special rules, they are typically used for significant, complex, or controversial measures. In the 111th Congress, 5% of legislation receiving House floor action came up under a special rule reported by the Rules Committee. 94% were bills or joint resolutions, and 6% were simple or concurrent resolutions. 11% of lawmaking forms of legislation in the 111th Congress came up by Special Rule, with 96% originating in the House and sponsored by a majority party Member. In the 111th Congress, legislation is sometimes brought before the House of Representatives for consideration by unanimous consent. The Speaker has policies regulating these requests, requiring clearance with party leaders and committee leadership. 2% of legislation identified by LIS received House floor action through unanimous consent, with 44% being bills or joint resolutions and 56% being simple or concurrent resolutions. During the 111th Congress, the House Rule XXVIII, known as the "Gephardt Rule," allowed for automatic passage of a joint resolution altering the public debt limit after the adoption of a congressional budget resolution. This rule was repealed at the start of the 112th Congress. Less than 1% of lawmaking legislation in the 111th Congress was passed through the Gephardt Rule. During the 111th Congress, the Gephardt Rule allowed for automatic passage of a joint resolution altering the public debt limit after a congressional budget resolution. Less than 1% of bills and joint resolutions receiving floor action in the 111th Congress came up under the Gephardt Rule. Private bills apply to specific individuals, corporations, or institutions and are considered under special parliamentary procedures. Private bills are placed on a special Private Calendar and considered on designated days. During the 111th Congress, private bills were considered under special parliamentary procedures known as the "House as in Committee of the Whole." These bills may be debated and amended under the five-minute rule, but are usually passed without debate. In that Congress, no measures were brought to the floor via the call of the Private Calendar, and two private laws were enacted through Suspension of the Rules. The House has established procedures for legislation related to the District of Columbia, including a discharge petition and a special parliamentary procedure. During the 111th Congress, special parliamentary procedures like the "House as in Committee of the Whole" were used for private bills. These bills were often passed without debate. In contrast, no legislation was brought before the House in that Congress using procedures like the discharge petition or the Calendar Wednesday procedure.
